sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Heart failure, (NYHA class II to IV, ejection fraction 40% or less) to reduce cardiovascular mortality and hospitalizations: initial, 4 mg ORALLY once daily, double dose at approximately 2-wk intervals, as tolerated; target dose 32 mg daily
  • Hypertension: initial, 16 mg ORALLY once daily or in 2 divided doses; range 8 to 32 mg ORALLY once daily or in 2 divided doses

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• not indicated for use in children less than 1 year of age
  • Hypertension: (1 to less than 6 yr), initial, 0.2 mg/kg once daily; dose range 0.05 to 0.4 mg/kg once daily or in 2 divided doses
  • Hypertension: less than 50 kg, (6 to less than 17 yr), initial, 4 to 8 mg ORALLY once daily; dose range 2 to 16 mg/day once daily or in 2 divided doses
  • Hypertension: greater than 50 kg, (6 to less than 17 yr), initial, 8 to 16 mg ORALLY once daily; dose range 4 to 32 mg/day once daily or in 2 divided doses

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal insufficiency: no initial dose adjustment necessary
  • renal impairment, moderate to severe (CrCl 15 to 60 mL/min/1.73 m(2)): 8 mg daily may be a sufficient dose
  • hepatic insufficiency, mild: no dose adjustment necessary
  • hepatic insufficiency, moderate: initiate therapy with 8 mg in adults with hypertension
  • hepatic insufficiency, severe: no dose recommendation available
  • geriatric: no initial dose adjustment necessary

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Heart failure, (NYHA class II to IV, ejection fraction 40% or less) to reduce cardiovascular mortality and hospitalizations
  • Hypertension
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Cerebrovascular accident; Prophylaxis
  • Diabetic nephropathy
  • Essential hypertension - Left ventricular hypertrophy
  • Kidney disease
  • Migraine; Prophylaxis
  • Recurrent atrial fibrillation; Prophylaxis
  • Transplantation

2.title: Black Box Warning
2.mono:
Oral (Tablet)
Drugs that act directly on the renin-angiotensin system can cause injury or death to the developing fetus. Stop therapy as soon as possible when pregnancy is detected.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to candesartan
  • concomitant use with aliskiren in patients with diabetes

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• pregnancy; risk of fetal toxicity, especially in the second and third trimesters; discontinue therapy as soon as possible when pregnancy is detected
  • concomitant use with aliskiren; avoid use in patients with GFR below 60 mL/min
  • hepatic impairment, moderate; consider dose reduction
  • hyperkalemia may occur; monitoring recommended
  • hypotension may occur, including during major surgery and anesthesia; increased risk in volume- or salt-depleted patients; correct volume and salt depletion before therapy initiation; monitoring recommended; dose reduction may be required
  • pediatric patients younger than 1 year; drug may affect kidney development; avoid use for hypertension
  • renal function changes, including acute renal failure, may occur from drugs that inhibit the renin-angiotensin system (RAAS); increased risk in patients whose renal function relies on the RAAS (eg, renal artery stenosis, chronic renal disease, severe heart failure, or volume depletion); monitoring recommended; therapy interruption or discontinuation may be required
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Systemic: Candesartan is a nonpeptide angiotensin II antagonist that selectively blocks the binding of angiotensin II to the AT 1 receptors in tissues such as vascular smooth muscle and the adrenal gland . In the renin-angiotensin system, angiotensin I is converted by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) to form angiotensin II . Angiotensin II stimulates the adrenal cortex to synthesize and secrete aldosterone, which decreases the excretion of sodium and increases the excretion of potassium . Angiotensin II also acts as a vasoconstrictor in vascular smooth muscle . By blocking the binding of angiotensin II to the AT 1 receptors, candesartan causes vasodilation and decreases the effects of aldosterone . The negative feedback regulation of angiotensin II on renin secretion also is inhibited, resulting in a rise in plasma renin concentrations and a consequent rise in angiotensin II plasma concentrations; however, these effects do not counteract the blood pressure-lowering effect that occurs .

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, Oral: 3 to 4 hr
  • Bioavailability, Oral: 15%
  • Effect of food: overall, no effect

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Intestinal wall: greater than 99%
  • Candesartan: active
  • Liver: minor
  • O-deethyl metabolite: inactive

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Bile: some contribution
  • Fecal: 67% unchanged
  • Renal: 26% unchanged
  • Renal clearance: 0.19 mL/min/kg
  • Dialyzable: No
  • Total body clearance: 0.37 mL/minute/kg

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • may be administered with or without food
  • candesartan oral suspension can be prepared within the range of 0.1 to 2 mg/mL (typically 1 mg/mL); use Ora-Plus(R) and Ora-Sweet SF(R) or Ora-Blend SF(R) as vehicle, and dispense the suspension in an amber polyethylene terephthalate (PET) bottle with an expiration date of 100 days when stored at room temperature

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• heart failure: decreased signs and symptoms of heart failure
  • hypertension: blood pressure
  • heart failure patients: renal function, serum potassium; periodically

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Generic
    Oral Tablet: 4 MG, 8 MG, 16 MG, 32 MG
  • Atacand
    Oral Tablet: 4 MG, 8 MG, 16 MG, 32 MG

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Patient should avoid activities requiring mental alertness or coordination until drug effects are realized.
  • This drug may cause dizziness or headache.
  • Instruct patients with a history of heart failure to report signs/symptoms of hypotension.
